instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01827: What is 820-01827? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 19v but missing VBUS on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>..
threads.message:
Hi Gents!

Water damage <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
[LIST=1]
[*]Stuck at 5v.
[*]Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. The problem was <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> (CPU PHASE IC 2) changed the IC.
[*]<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> outputs: <SIGNAL>LDO3_3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LDO1_8A</SIGNAL>
[*]Now I have 20v and stuck on 0.052 AMP, but missing VBUS (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) shows 0v...  How is that possible?
[/LIST]
Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 19v but missing VBUS on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>..
threads.message:
Hopeless project, most likely dead CPU; overvoltage through <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>.

VBUS appears only at one port; depends where you connect the charger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 19v but missing VBUS on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>..
threads.message: I see.. ok.. Yes, might be the CPU.... it took ages to change out the <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>... the whole board was bloody hot.. could be when I did the change.. unless it was shorted as you said.. will double-check and revert back. thanks master

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01827</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 19v but missing VBUS on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>..
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73745, member: 682"]
Hopeless project, most likely dead CPU; overvoltage through <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>.

VBUS appears only at one port; depends where you connect the charger.
[/QUOTE]
Yes, CPU badly shorted... after double checking...

Thanks, Master... Case closed!
